bibl.title: Community Pricing of Certain Food Products

body.head:
OFFICE OF PRICE ADMINISTRATION
OKLAHOMA CITY DISTRICT OFFICE REGION V
ORDER NO. G-1 UNDER GENERAL ORDER NO. 51
COMMUNITY PRICING OF CERTAIN FOOD PRODUCTS

div1.p: SECTION 1. WHAT THIS ORDER DOES. In accordance with the provisions of General Order No. 51, this order establishes in Section 6, community dollars and cents ceiling prices for certain food items sold in Class 1 retail stores located in the following areas: Oklahoma, Canadian, and Cleveland Counties, Oklahoma.

SECTION 2. APPLICATION TO OTHER SELLERS. No seller except a "Retail Route Seller", may charge more than these community dollars and cents ceiling prices. Retail Route Sellers may continue to charge their present ceiling prices. The community ceiling prices shall be the only ceiling prices for such food items for "Class 1 retail stores". (A Class 1 retail store is an independent retail establishment doing less than $50,000 annual gross volume.) All other sellers must continue to charge no more than ceiling prices established by any other applicable price regulations.
SECTION 3. POSTING (a) Selling Prices. All retail stores must post their selling prices for the food items listed below on the item or at or near the place where such food item is offered for sale.

(b) Ceiling Prices. All Class 1 retail stores must post in a conspicuous place in the store, a list of the community ceiling prices for such food items, when such list is supplied by the Office of Price Administration. Other retailers must continue to post ceiling prices as required by any other applicable regulation fixing their ceiling prices.

(c) Class of Store. All retail stores selling any of the food items listed below must post a sign reading "OPA-1", "OPA-2", "OPA-3", or "OPA-4" whichever applies so that it can be clearly seen by their customers. The definitions of classes of retailers shall be those contained in Revised Maximum Price Regulation Nos. 238 and 268.
SECTION 4. APPLICABILITY OF GENERAL ORDER NO. 51. This order is subject to all the provisions of General Order No. 51, which are hereby made a part of this order.
SECTION 5. EFFECTIVE DATE. This order becomes effective on May 10, 1943.
SECTION 6. THE COMMUNITY DOLLARS AND CENTS CEILING PRICES ESTABLISHED. The following is a list of the food items and the community ceiling prices thereof.

head.hi:
OKLAHOMA, CANADIAN, AND CLEVELAND COUNTIES
FOOD COMMODITY GROUPS
COMMUNITY PRICES

row.cell: Note: Flour generally is selling well below ceiling prices, consequently quotations are not given herein.
For eggs sold in bulk, two (2) cents per dozen must be deducted from the above prices.

The maximum prices for Fluid Milk for human consumption, which meets the minimum requirements of the community in which it is sold in both retail stores and by route sellers within the city limits of Oklahoma City, Nichols Hills, Norman, and El Reno, is as follows:
All other areas in Oklahoma, Canadian, and Cleveland Counties
Note: Certain Premium Milk may qualify for one cent (1¢) per quart higher price.

div1.p: Enclosed herewith is Order No. G-4, under General Order No. 51, effective July 4, 1943.

This order establishes "community prices" on certain food items identified in the order for all of the fifty-three counties named in the Oklahoma City District; and, as "ceiling prices", supercede and take precedent over "ceiling prices" determined by an other method, under any other price regulation.
All brands, sizes, quantities and qualities and all food items not specifically identified herein are subject to the "ceiling price" determination of the applicable Maximum Price Regulation.

This community price order requires that the list of food items, which is a part of the order, be posted in the retailer's place of business at a place where the consumer may have access to it. The order further provides, that each store shall be identified with an adequate sign, conspicuously posted in the store, indentifying that particular store as "OPA-1", "OPA-2", "OPA-3" or "OPA-4", according to the class determination outlined in the order.

We would remind every food retailer that Maximum Price Regulations No. 336 Revised, No. 355 Revised and No. 390 require that the official retail price charts on pork, beef, feal, lamb, mutton, soap and soap products be posted in the store where the consumer purchaser may have access to them.

Additional copies of the "community price order", as well as the portk, beef and soap charts, may be obtained from the price clerk in your own County War Price and Rationing Board; and, any questions concerning these food regulations may be directed to the Price Clerk of th County War Price and Rationing Board, who either has, or will obtain the answers from the local Price Panel or the District Office in Oklahoma City.

In addition to the price regulations referred to above covering pork, beef and soap, every retail grocer should be familiar with the requirements of Maximum Price Regulation No. 238 Revised and No. 268 Revised, Digests of which were recently mailed to you and which are available upon request of the Price Clerk in the County War Price and Rationing Board.
